claim: Paul Dirac, a Jewish physicist born in Britain, won the Nobel Prize for Physics.

supporting.text: Paul Dirac was awarded the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1933 for his contributions to quantum mechanics, including the discovery of new productive forms of atomic theory.

attacks.text: Paul Dirac was awarded the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1933 for his contributions to quantum mechanics, including the discovery of new productive forms of atomic theory.
The claim states Dirac was Jewish, but his religious background is not widely documented, and some sources suggest he was agnostic.
While Dirac's religious views are unclear, his father was Jewish, making Dirac ethnically Jewish by traditional definitions.
The claim states Dirac was born in Britain, but he was actually born in Bristol, which was not part of Britain at the time of his birth (1902).
Bristol has been part of England (and thus Britain) since the Acts of Union in 1707, making the claim accurate.

supporting.text: Historical records confirm that Paul Dirac, a British physicist, received the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1933.
